name: Yemen
currentCrisisSummary:
Yemen endures one of the world's most severe humanitarian catastrophes, directly caused by a protracted **proxy war** over state control and its **strategic position** on a key **global trade route**. The conflict, involving a **Saudi-led coalition** (backed by **Western arms**) and Iran-aligned forces, has been waged through **blockades**, **sieges**, and attacks on infrastructure, deliberately crippling the nation.

This violence and **externally imposed restrictions** have devastated the economy, wrecked public services, and produced **catastrophic hunger and disease**. Aid diversion exacerbates suffering. The crisis is actively sustained by **international arms flows**, **regional rivalries**, and **global economic interests** prioritising strategic gain over human life.

imperialRoot.imperialPower: Britain & Ottoman Empire (Aden 1839-1967; Ottoman presence in the north until 1918)
imperialRoot.legacy:
The crisis draws on deep **colonial-era divisions**. **British control** (south) alongside **Ottoman administration** (north) produced distinct legacies. Britain's **protectorates** and **indirect rule** hindered unity, leaving a **governance vacuum**.

These **colonial partitions**, plus later **Cold War geopolitics**, created fault-lines exploited by elites and **foreign powers**, contributing to cycles of conflict and **external intervention**.

historicalContext.title: Geopolitical Chokepoint and Global Trade
historicalContext.description: Yemen's geography astride the **Bab-el-Mandeb strait**, a vital **chokepoint** for **global trade**, makes it a theatre for **strategic competition**. **Regional powers** and global actors seek influence. Control of **maritime access** is a persistent objective for **external actors**.

historicalContext.title: Neoliberal Reforms and the Roots of Rebellion
historicalContext.description: Post-unification, Yemen faced **IMF/World Bank-led Structural Adjustment Programmes (SAPs)**. These **neoliberal 'reforms'** mandated lifting subsidies, **privatisation**, and severe **austerity**. Hardship affected marginalised regions, feeding grievances of southern secessionists and the northern **Houthi rebellion**. The Houthi rise was partly a revolt against **corruption** from this **Western-backed economic model**.

historicalContext.title: The War on Terror and Foreign Intervention
historicalContext.description: The current war was preceded by **US intervention** under the '**Global War on Terror**'. Saleh exploited **US counter-terrorism aid** primarily against domestic opponents (**Houthis**). This use of an **imperial security framework** radicalised opposition. Later supplanted by the current **proxy war**, sustained by **arms transfers** from Western nations to the **Saudi-led coalition**, enabling violations of **international law**.

historicalContext.title: International Law And Accountability
historicalContext.description: Allegations of unlawful attacks, **blockade-induced starvation**, and **aid diversion** prompt calls for **accountability**. UN bodies document potential **war crimes**. **Accountability** efforts remain politically contested but central to justice.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Hundreds of thousands killed (est. 377k by late 2021) directly by fighting or indirectly through **conflict-induced starvation and disease**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: Roughly 19.5 million require aid due to the systematic destruction caused by warring parties and their **international backers**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 17 million face acute hunger from **blockades**, attacks on agriculture, and **economic collapse caused by the war**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement
humanitarianImpact.description: Around 4.5 million internally displaced by bombing, fighting, and **climate shocks exacerbated by state failure**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugees
humanitarianImpact.description: Tens of thousands forced abroad by **extreme violence** created by the conflict.

humanitarianImpact.title: Healthcare Collapse
humanitarianImpact.description: Roughly half of health facilities non-functional due to attacks, lack of supplies from **blockades**, and infrastructure collapse.

humanitarianImpact.title: Lack of Water Access
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 15 million lack safe water/sanitation due to **infrastructure destruction** and import restrictions.

humanitarianImpact.title: Education Denied
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 2 million children denied education as schools damaged or inaccessible due to conflict.

timeline.event: **British seize Aden**: The British Empire captures the port of Aden, beginning a prolonged colonial presence in southern Yemen that would shape later regional divisions.
**Ottoman withdrawal & fragmented rule**: Ottoman influence in the north recedes after World War I; multiple sultanates, imamates and protectorates coexist until mid-20th century state formations.
**Unification**: North (Yemen Arab Republic) and South (People's Democratic Republic of Yemen) formally unite. Structural economic and political differences produce long-standing grievances.

**Civil War & Neoliberal Riots**: A short but bitter civil war deepens southern grievances. The conflict is exacerbated by widespread popular anger against IMF-mandated austerity measures imposed after unification.

**"War on Terror" & Houthi Uprising**: The US expands counter-terror operations, including drone strikes. The Saleh regime uses US military aid to suppress domestic opponents, particularly the nascent Houthi rebellion, which is also fuelled by anger at economic marginalisation.

**Houthi advance & coalition intervention**: Houthi forces seize large parts of the country, including Sana'a; a Saudi-led coalition launches an air and naval campaign and enforces blockades, precipitating the large-scale humanitarian catastrophe that follows.

**Protracted humanitarian catastrophe**: Years of siege, economic collapse, aid displacement and repeated attacks on infrastructure create a chronic humanitarian emergency that the UN repeatedly describes as among the worldâ€™s worst.

Provides life-saving food, child protection services, and cash assistance to families who have lost everything in the ongoing war.
A Yemeni-led diaspora organisation providing direct aid, cash assistance and advocacy for reconstruction and peace.

advocacy.title: End Blockades and Sieges
advocacy.description: Demand an immediate end to blockades and sieges and insist on unimpeded, independent humanitarian access to all civilians.

advocacy.title: Suspend Arms Transfers
advocacy.description: Call on Western and regional governments to suspend arms transfers that enable indiscriminate attacks and to condition support on respect for international humanitarian law.

advocacy.title: Support Yemeni-Led Peace
advocacy.description: Support Yemeni-led peace initiatives and ensure that any diplomatic settlement protects civilians, restores services and addresses economic and political grievances.

advocacy.title: Demand Accountability
advocacy.description: Push for independent investigations into alleged war crimes and for accountability mechanisms that centre victims' rights and reparations.

reading.title: *Destroying Yemen: What Chaos in Arabia Tells Us about the World*
reading.description: Isa Blumi's critical history linking Yemen's modern conflicts to longer legacies of imperial intervention and regional power struggles.

reading.title: *Yemen in Crisis: Autocracy, Neo-Liberalism and the Disintegration of a State*
reading.description: Helen Lackner provides a detailed study of the political, social, and economic drivers, including neoliberal policies, that led to Yemen's current war.

reading.title: *Yemen Endures: Civil War, Saudi Adventurism and the Future of Arabia*
reading.description: Edited by Ginny Hill, et al. This collection analyses governance failures, the impact of neoliberalism, and regional interventions contributing to state collapse.
